title: Sabal bermudana
text:
Sabal bermudana, commonly known as the Bermuda palmetto or bibby-tree, is one of 15 species of <a href="Arecaceae">palm trees</a> in the genus "<a href="Sabal">Sabal</a>" and is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to <a href="Bermuda">Bermuda</a> although reportedly naturalized in the <a href="Leeward%20Islands">Leeward Islands</a>. It was greatly affected by the introduction of non-native plants such as the <a href="Livistona%20chinensis">Chinese fan palm</a>, which created competition for space that it usually lost.
Description.
"Sabal bermudana" grows up to in height, with the occasional old tree growing up to in height, with a trunk up to in diameter. It is a fan palm (Arecaceae tribe <a href="Corypheae">Corypheae</a>), with the leaves with a bare <a href="petiole%20%28botany%29">petiole</a> terminating in a rounded fan of numerous <a href="leaflet%20%28botany%29">leaflets</a>. Each <a href="leaf">leaf</a> is long, with 45-60 leaflets up to long. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are yellowish-white, across, produced in large <a href="panicle">panicle</a>s up to long, extending out beyond the leaves. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a deep brown to black <a href="drupe">drupe</a> about long containing a single <a href="seed">seed</a>. It is extremely <a href="Halophyte">salt-tolerant</a> and is often seen growing near the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> coast in Bermuda, and also <a href="Hardy%20palms">frost-tolerant</a>, surviving short periods of temperatures as low as -14 °C, although no such temperatures have ever occurred in Bermuda.
Uses.
Bermudians used to use, for a short period, the leaflets of the palm to weave into hats and export them to the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> and other countries. "Sabal bermudana" also had holes drilled into its trunk and <a href="sap">sap</a> extracted to make "bibby", a strong <a href="Palm%20wine">alcoholic beverage</a>.
During the 17th century, most <a href="architecture%20of%20Bermuda">houses in Bermuda</a> had palmetto-<a href="Thatching">thatched</a> roofs.
